questions.text: In Zenker’s diverticulum, Killian’s dehiscence is a potential space in the ………….muscle.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Inferior constrictor

In Zenker’s diverticulum. It protrudes through the Killian’s dehiscence, a potential space present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

choices.text: Long head of triceps and brachialis
Long head of triceps and biceps brachii

questions.text: Which of the following muscles cross both the shoulder and elbow joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Long head of triceps and biceps brachii

The long head of triceps and biceps brachii cross both shoulder and elbow joints, hence acting on both joints.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first committed step of glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Fructose 6 phosphate to Fructose 1, 6 bisphosphate
 

Fructose 6 phosphate to fructose 1,6 bisphosphate catalyzed by PFK-1 is the first commited step of glycolysis. As fructose 1,6 bisphosphate once formed, it cannot revert back and go into any pathway other than glycolysis.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which of the following proteins during smooth muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Calmodulin

Calcium binds to calmodulin during smooth muscle contraction. Increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ binds to and activates calcium- binding proteins (calmodulin, troponin) or activates protein kinases (or phospholipase C) to bring about physiological effects.

questions.text: A patient presents with drooping of angle of mouth and inability to blow. Which of the following nerve is involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

7

Facial nerve, called the 7th cranial nerve, travels through a narrow, bony canal in the skull. The nerve controls sensation and helps move tiny muscles in the face. If the nerve is damaged and stops functioning it can cause the face to droop. It can also affect tear ducts and taste sensations from the tongue.

questions.text: Muscle cannot release glucose from glycogen because of the deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glucose-6-phosphatase

Muscles cannot release glucose into the blood due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. Glucose-6-phosphatase is present in the lumen of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes. Hence, hepatocytes can convert glucose-6-phosphate into glucose and release glycogen-derived glucose into the blood in order to maintain blood glucose levels stable, until gluconeogenesis kicks in.

questions.text: Which is the most prominent EEG wave recorded in a subject who is awake but eyes closed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alpha waves

Alpha waves are the most prominent waves seen in adults at rest, i.e. awake but relaxed with eyes closed.

questions.text: Ptyalin is secreted by which of the following glands?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Salivary gland

Ptyalin (salivary a-amylase) is secreted by the salivary gland.

There are 3 pairs of salivary glands

Parotid

Submandibular

Sublingual glands

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct relationship with regards to the saphenous nerve in the adductor canal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Answer: Anterior to femoral artery

The saphenous nerve is anterior to the femoral artery in the adductor canal.

questions.text: Which of the following two monosaccharides are constituents of lactulose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Galactose and Fructose

Lactulose is a disaccharide composed of two simple sugars, galactose and fructose linked by a ẞ-1,4-glycosidic linkage.

questions.text: All of the following muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Palatoglossus

Palatoglossus is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes (hence innervated by the hypoglossal nerve), except palatoglossus, which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the vago- accessory nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is secreted by the zona glomerulosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aldosterone

The adrenal cortex has three zones. From outer to inner, they are:

•    Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (Aldosterone)

•    Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (Cortisol and corticosterone)

•    Zona reticularis: Secretes sex steroids (dehydroepiandrosterone, androstenedione, estrogens, and glucocorticoids)

The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines.

questions.text: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Angiotensin II

The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is Angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance and decreases Nat and H₂O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male had undergone resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of which of the following hormones is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gastrin

Serum levels of the gastrin are most likely to be reduced. Gastrin is secreted by the G cells in the gastric antrum. Gastrin has two main actions: Stimulates secretion of H+ by gastric parietal cells Promotes growth of the gastric mucosa (trophic action). Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the shown in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 

Noncompetitive inhibitor
The line in the graph represents a reaction with Noncompetitive inhibitor. Noncompetitive inhibition, a type of allosteric regulation, is a specific type of enzyme inhibition characterized by an inhibitor binding to an allosteric site resulting in decreased efficacy of the enzyme. An allosteric site differs from the active site- where the substrate binds.

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporter in the myocytes is under the influence of insulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 

GLUT 4 
 

GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter in the myocytes under the influence of insulin.
Glucose transport in our body mainly occurs through sodium- independent glucose transporters, which include GLUT transporters and to a small extent through sodium-dependent glucose transporters, which include SGLT-1 and SGLT-2. Insulin induces the movement of intracellular GLUT 4. Molecules to the cell surface and thus increases glucose uptake. In type 2 diabetes mellitus, membrane GLUT 4 is reduced, leading to insulin resistance in muscle and fat cells.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination,there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which is the nerve most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Musculocutaneous nerve 

The given clinical vignette in a patient with difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, with associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of injury to the musculocutaneous nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the nerve supply of the kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Coeliac plexus

The coeliac plexus contributes to the nerve supply of the kidneys.

questions.text: In a patient with maple syrup urine disease, all of the following amino acids should be restricted in diet except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Methionine
In maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), only branched-chain amino acids are restricted, hence, methionine does not need any restriction in diet.
Branched-chain amino acids are:
- Leucine (L)
- Isoleucine (I)
- Valine (V)

questions.text: What joint is present between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Synchondrosis

The joint present between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone is called synchondrosis.

choices.text: At the junction of L1 & L2
At the junction of L2 & L3
At the junction of T12 & L1
At the junction of L3 & L4

questions.text: To what level of vertebrae does the marked structure correspond?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

At the junction of L3 & L4

The structure marked in the given image is the umbilicus and it corresponds to the level of the junction between the third and fourth lumbar vertebrae (L3 & L4).

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady has regular, infrequent menstrual cycles occurring at an interval of 35-36 days. What is the usual timing of ovulation in this lady?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

14 days before menstruation

Ovulation occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. If we calculate the day of menstruation from the beginning of the cycle, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14 and in a 35-day cycle, ovulation will occur on day 22.

questions.text: A 12-year old boy fell down while playing and sustained a supracondylar fracture of humerus leading to vascular injury. Which of the following would be the least affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pain sensation

The vascular injury following a supracondylar fracture of humerus will least affect pain sensation. In this case, the boy’s fracture and injury to the brachial artery could result in hypoxic injury to the nerves. An arterial injury would affect regions of nerves supplied by it. Pain sensation would be least affected following a hypoxic injury.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with burning pain and numbness in his hands, heat intolerance and decreased visual acuity. Further evaluation reveals skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

X-linked recessive
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Fabry’s disease which is inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder. Fabry’s disease is a lipid storage disorder due to a deficiency of a-Galactosidase, resulting in the accumulation of Globotriaosyl-ceramide in tissues.

questions.text: A group of scientists is studying a protein. They electrophorese the protein and transfer it to a membrane. The proteins are visualized by tagging them to specific antibodies. This procedure is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Western blot

The above procedure depicts Western blot technique. This technique is used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is most likely to be injured in a wrist slash injury over the radial side of the left wrist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Median nerve

Median nerve is more likey to be injured in case of deep laceration of radial side of the wrist. Wrist slash injuries: A deep laceration on the radial side of the wrist may injure the radial artery, median nerve, flexor carpi radialis tendon, and palmaris longus tendon.

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in paediatric department where a mother brings her child with fatigue bleeding gums and joint pain and petechial haemorrhage under skin. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The child presents with fatigue, bleeding gums, joint pain, and petechial hemorrhages — all classical signs of Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy).
Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is essential for collagen synthesis, wound healing, and maintaining the integrity of blood vessels.
Deficiency leads to defective collagen formation, resulting in fragile capillaries, bleeding gums, subperiosteal hemorrhages, and bone pain (due to impaired osteoid formation).

The next step in management is to start high-dose Vitamin C supplementation along with dietary advice to include citrus fruits, amla, guava, and other vitamin C–rich foods.

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.text: A middle-aged man who is a chronic alcoholic presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the protocol to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke’s encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke’s encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

questions.text: During surgery for patent ductus arteriosus, which anatomical structure is most susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is most susceptible to injury during surgery for patent ductus arteriosus. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the 6th arch artery while the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the 4th arch artery. This occurs because the distal portion of the 6th arch disappears on the right side along with the 5th arch artery. Thus the nerve on the right side loops under the 4th arch artery.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented with sudden onset of loss of pain and temperature on the right side of his face and left side of his body. He also has dysphagia and dysarthria. Thrombosis of which vessel is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

The given clinical features are suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome, which is seen in thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

questions.text: All of the following transport mechanisms are rate limited by an intrinsic Vmax, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Simple diffusion

Simple diffusion is not mediated by carrier, and hence, the rate of simple diffusion shows a linear relationship with increase in concentration of the substance, and there is no intrinsic maximum velocity (Vmax).

questions.text: Which of the following events cannot be seen in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Atrial repolarization 

Atrial repolarization cannot be seen on a normal ECG. Atrial repolarization occurs during the ventricular depolarization. However, the voltage of the atrial repolarization is very low and is masked by the QRS complex representing ventricular depolarization.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fracture of the structure marked below following a road traffic accident. Which of the following symptoms will be seen in this is patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anosmia

The structure marked in the given image is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid and fracture to the cribriform plate will lead to anosmia as the olfactory nerve fibres pierce through it.

questions.text: Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in which of the following vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vitamin B6

Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate), a coenzyme required by kynureninase enzyme to convert 3-OH kynurenine to 3-OH anthranilic acid during tryptophan metabolism.

questions.text: Given histology pic is of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fibro Cartilage

Fibrocartilage is the tough, very strong tissue found predominantly in the intervertebral disks and at the insertions of ligaments and tendons; it is similar to other fibrous tissues but contains cartilage ground substance and chondrocytes.

questions.text: All mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Hunter's disease
All mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except Hunter's disease which is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase of the below image is the action potential most dependant on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Phase 0
The action potential is most dependent on sodium permeability during phase 0.
Action potential of the myocardium:
Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage-regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: The CT scan of a 1-week old infant revealed the absence of greater cornu of the hyoid and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3rd pharyngeal arch

Greater horn (greater cornu) and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone are formed from the 3rd pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones increases during starvation, stress, and deep sleep?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Growth hormone
Growth hormone increases during starvation, stress, and deep sleep.
Stimuli that increase GH secretion:
- Hypoglycemia, deoxyglucose, fasting, starvation
- Exercise
- Protein meal, infusion of arginine
- Glucagon
- Deep sleep
- Estrogens and androgens
- Stressful stimuli
Growth hormone is secreted from the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. Its main role is the growth of the human body.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented with resting tremors, difficulty in initiating movements, poor balance, and frequent falls. What is the site of the lesion of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Substantia nigra

The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Parkinson’s disease, and the site of the lesion is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson’s disease, also known as paralysis agitans. It shows an accumulation of synucleins. Bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremors, and postural instability are classic features of Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: Fluoroacetate is a component of pesticides. Which of the following metabolic pathways is inhibited by this compound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

TCA cycle
Fluoroacetate inhibits the TCA cycle enzyme aconitase.
Fluoroacetyl CoA condenses with oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate which inhibits aconitase, causing citrate to accumulate. This way it inhibits TCA cycle enzyme non- competitively.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed vasopressin. This drug has its maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Collecting duct 

Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts. Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (CAMP), and otein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting protein duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.

questions.text: A 3-month-old female child was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. On examination, generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. The chest x-ray shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. Which of the following is the enzyme most likely to be involved in the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Pompe's disease. This disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. Pompe's disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a-1,4- glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency. It causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not present in the mitochondrial matrix?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 

ATP synthase 
 

ATP synthase is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane, not mitochondrial matrix.

questions.text: In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, which of the following corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Point B to Point C

In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, the event that occurs between Points B and C is iso-volumetric contraction, which corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP. In iso-volumetric contraction, the ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

questions.text: Transport of lipid-soluble substances across the cell membrane occurs via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diffusion

Lipid-soluble substances are transported across the cell membrane via diffusion.

Passive diffusion is a process by which a lipid-soluble molecule is able to freely cross in and out of the cell by dissolving itself in the phospholipid bilayer

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Opening of calcium channels

The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch- induced by opening of calcium channels. The mechanism is called Myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. Stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular resistance.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alkaptonuria

Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria. Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/homogentisic acid 1, 2- dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following mucopolysaccharidosis does not show leukocyte inclusions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Morquio Disease
 

Morquio disease does not show leukocyte inclusions. Morquio disease is different from other mucopolysaccharidoses as it presents as spondyloepiphyseal skeletal dysplasia.

questions.text: The image shows the cross-section of the abdominal cavity. Identify the structure marked ‘A’.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Descending aorta

In the given image, the structure marked ‘A’ corresponds to the descending aorta.

questions.text: G6PD can manifest with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
G6PD deficiency will manifest with primaquine. G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder that causes congenital hemolytic anemia due to enzyme deficiency. Hemolysis occurs in conditions of high oxidative stress that are triggered by infections, fava beans, and certain drugs. G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that maintains the cellular levels of NADPH. NADPH then provides reducing equivalents needed for the conversion of oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione. Reduced glutathione helps neutralize free radicles, protecting against oxidant injury.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory test result of leptospira IgM reactivity, now presented with breathlessness, fever, and jaundice that worsened after treatment with penicillin. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The possible diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction. JHR is a condition that occurs in patients infected by spirochetes who undergo antibiotic treatment. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic treatment. Clinical features are fever, chills, nausea and vomiting, tachycardia, hypotension, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions. JHR is due to IL6, TNF-alpha, and IL 8. Syphilis is the leading spirochetal infection associated with JHR. Other infections are Lyme disease, louse-borne relapsing fever, leptospirosis, and tick-borne relapsing fever. Antibiotics that have been most associated are penicillins, tetracyclines, and erythromycin. Mild reactions are self-limiting and often resolve spontaneously within 24 hours. Prevention of the JHR is by giving TNF-alpha antibodies and steroids.

questions.text: Which of the following vectors is associated with Orientia Tsutsugamushi?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trombiculid mite
Trombiculid mite is the vector responsible for the transmission of scrub typhus caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy from Bihar was rushed to the emergency department with a headache, fever, and blurred vision followed shortly by unresponsiveness to verbal commands. He is suspected to have viral encephalitis. Which of the following transmits this endemic disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Endemic viral encephalitis is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnuii. It is the leading cause of childhood neurological viral infection in India. In endemic areas such as North India, it typically affects children <15 years of age as by early adulthood, the majority of the population has protective immunity following natural exposure to the virus.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis develops ascites. What is the drug of choice for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone. Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels.

questions.text: What does the area between the dotted lines in this graph indicate? .
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


The area between the dotted lines in the graph shows the therapeutic window. It is the range of steady-state concentrations of a drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity.

choices.text: Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.text: The drug of choice in anaphylactic shock is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 by intramuscular route (IM) is the drug of choice for treatment of anaphylactic shock. Hence it is the answer here. In case the patient develops life threatening condition, adrenaline 0.25 mg IV is given.

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dilated cardiomyopathy

Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy Alcohol and its metabolites, especially acetaldehyde have a direct toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Pencil-shaped macroconidia is a feature of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trichophyton

Pencil-shaped macroconidia is a feature of trichophyton.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bcl-2

BCI-2 is an anti-apoptotic factor. The intrinsic pathway of apoptosis is initiated by the permeabilization of the mitochondrial membrane. This is facilitated by pro-apoptotic proteins (BAX and BAK) and inhibited by anti-apoptotic proteins.

questions.text: A Kinyoun-positive oocyst (25 µm) isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea is shown in the image. What is the likely organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The given clinical scenario with diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. Kinyoun- positive oocysts with the size of 25 µm in the image are formed by Cystoisospora.

questions.text: By which of the following mechanisms is penicillin resistance commonly transferred to Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Transduction

Penicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is determined by plasmids that are most commonly transferred by transduction. Conjugation is the most common method of transfer of antibiotic resistance in most other bacteria.

questions.text: Match the following cell types with their associated malignancy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The correct matches are as follows:


 
Popcorn cell is a lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed Steenberg (RS) cells that are characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. It has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn. The image below shows a popcorn cell seen in lymphocytic predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alzheimer's disease

Among the choices provided, Alzheimer's disease is most commonly associated with Down's syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following are decreased in acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Albumin Albumin levels can decrease during acute inflammation due to increased capillary permeability and leakage of albumin into the extravascular space.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis. Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old truck driver presents with painful multiple ulcers on his penis 3 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chancroid
Multiple painful genital ulcers 3 days after unprotected Intercourse is indicative of Chancroid or Soft Chancre. Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, a gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called “kissing ulcers.”

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except____.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Abdominal tuberculosis (TB) is not transmitted by feco-oral route. The terminal ileum and the cecum are the sites most commonly involved in abdominal TB. It causes abdominal pain (at times similar to that associated with appendicitis) and obstruction, hematochezia, palpable mass in the abdomen along with fever, weight loss, anorexia, and night sweats.

questions.text: Iron in tissues is stained by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in histopathological studies to detect the presence of iron in the specimen. Iron is stained blue with this stain. It is used in hereditary hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, which shows hepatocellular iron. It also stains the iron-laden mitochondria of ring sideroblasts seen in lead toxicity and myelodysplastic syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with dry cough, low-grade fever and wheezing. He is diagnosed with Loeffler’s syndrome. Which of the following parasites does not cause this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Loeffler’s syndrome is an eosinophilic inflammation of thelung caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralisand Necator americanus. Enterobius vermicularis does not cause Loeffler’s syndrome. It is associated with pneumonia characterized by dry cough.low-grade fever, wheezing, urticaria, and eosinophilia.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient complains of wheezing and shortness of breath most days of the week. Which of the following therapies is preferred in him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
This patient has persistent asthma for which the preferred therapy is LABA with ICS available as a combination inhaler. ICS should be started in any patient who needs to use a short-acting beta-2 agonist inhaler for symptomatic control more than twice a week (persistent asthma).

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with colicky abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. Urinalysis shows only red blood cells with no other significant findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

IgA vasculitis IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), commonly presents with colicky abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura, often in the lower extremities. The presence of red blood cells in the urine is also consistent with this condition.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) binds to CD21 and acts as a B-cell mitogen. It affects adolescents and younger adults more frequently but may occur from childhood to old age. It is transmitted primarily through close contact with oropharyngeal secretions. The incubation period of EBV infectious mononucleosis is 4-6 weeks.

questions.text: An elderly patient with dementia is not compliant with oral medications. Which of the following will be beneficial in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Rivastigmine transdermal patch can be prescribed to patients with dementia who are non compliant on oral medications. Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is available as a transdermal patch for use in alzheimer’s disease and dementia. It can be applied for over 24 hours. Transdermal delivery reduces the fluctuation and avoids direct gastric irritation effects associated with oral formulations.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis. The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with meningitis is on chloramphenicol therapy. Which of the following blood dyscrasias as a side effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Aplastic anemia

The patient is most likely to have aplastic anemia, as it is the most common blood dyscrasia associated with the use of chloramphenicol. It can lead to fatal pancytopenia that has a high rate of mortality.

questions.text: A male patient presents with hydrophobia, tearing, and altered sensorium after a dog bite. You suspect rabies in this patient and take corneal scrapings to confirm the same. What test is performed to obtain the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reverse transcription-PCR for virus

Detection of rabies virus RNA by RT-PCR(reverse transcriptase -polymerase chain reaction) on corneal scrapings is highly sensitive and specific.

questions.text: The following is a histopathological image of thyroid pathology. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in diabetic neuropathy, post herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pregabalin can be used for diabetic neuropathy, post herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury. Although amitriptyline can also be used for these conditions, pregabalin is found to be recommended over amitriptyline considering safety and efficacy and hence is the best option.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis in a patient who has undergone organ transplantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cotrimoxazole
Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis in Immunocompromised patients like patients who have undergone organ transplantation and HIV-positive patients.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects does the drug have on the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Premature closure of ductus arteriosus

Indomethacin can cause premature closure of ductus arteriosus if given to a pregnant woman. Indomethacin is approved for the closure of persistent ductus arteriosus in premature infants. It is given intravenously. One of its limiting factors is the development of renal toxicity in neonates.

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cytotoxic T cell 
Cytotoxic T cells are involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever caused by nairovirus has an endemic transmission in India. An outbreak was recognized in Gujarat in 2011. In India, antibodies against the virus have been detected in human and animal sera. It is transmitted by hyalomma ticks.

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Vigabatrin is particularly effective in infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis and is considered the first-line treatment in this condition.

questions.text: Most specific feature of the disease associated with karyotype shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Coarctation of Aorta
The diagnosis is Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome (TS) has a 45,X karyotype. The clinical features of TS result from haploinsufficiency of multiple X chromosomal genes (e.g., Short Stature Homeobox, SHOX). TS is characterized by bilateral streak gonads, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and multiple congenital anomalies in phenotypic females. Prenatally, a diagnosis of TS is usually made incidentally after chorionic villous sampling or amniocentesis for unrelated reasons, such as advanced maternal age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of diarrhea and flask-shaped ulcers in the intestine. Microscopic findings reveal quadrinucleated cysts. Which of the following can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Metronidazole + Paromomycin
This patient’s clinical features of diarrhea and flask-shaped ulcers with quadrinucleate cysts are suggestive of amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is metronidazole (or tinidazole) + a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin, diloxanide furoate, or iodoquinone.

questions.text: A patient with polycystic kidney disease came to the ER with complaints of severe headache. An NCCT brain was taken and it showed subarachnoid hemorrhage. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


 Nimodipine is the most appropriate drug that can be given to this patient. Nimodipine is indicated in cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. It has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce mortality after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: Chromosomal abnormalities seen in follicular lymphoma is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

t(14;18)
Follicular lymphoma shows T(14;18). It arises from germinal center B cells. It is strongly associated with chromosomal translocations involving BCL2. Its hallmark is (14;18) translocation.

questions.text: A patient is started on hormone replacement for chronic adrenal insufficiency. What is the replacement dose of hydrocortisone that has to be given (in mg/day)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

20

The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for chronic adrenal insufficiency is 20 mg/day. The treatment of chronic adrenal insufficiency (not in crisis) requires glucocorticoid replacement at a dose that replaces the physiologic daily cortisol production. This is achieved by administering an oral replacement dose of 15-25mg Hydrocortisone.

questions.text: What is the most common adverse effect of phenytoin in children and young adolescents on chronic use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Gingival hyperplasia occurs in patients on chronic phenytoin therapy. It is the most common manifestation in children and young adolescents.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with lower back pain and fever. During history-taking, he mentions experiencing multiple similar episodes in the past. Amylase also increased. Which type of necrosis is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fat necrosis Chronic alcoholism can lead to pancreatitis, which often results in fat necrosis, particularly in the abdominal area. This type of necrosis involves the destruction of fat cells and the release of fatty acids, which can combine with calcium to form soap-like deposits, commonly seen in pancreatic disease.

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fibrinoid necrosis

Immune reactions involving blood vessels, as seen in the case of polyarteritis nodosa, usually show fibrinoid necrosis. Fibrinoid means fibrin-like. In some immune disorders, the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessels. These complexes result in complement activation (type III hypersensitivity) leading to cell injury. This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around the blood vessels.

questions.text: Which is a selective endothelin receptor A antagonist used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Ambrisentan is a selective endothelin receptor A (ET-A) antagonist which is used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH).

questions.text: Hereditary angioedema is due to a defect in which of the proteins mentioned below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, their deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin.

questions.text: Metastatic calcification can be explained by all, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Metastatic calcification cannot be explained by vitamin D deficiency. Metastatic calcification is associated with hypercalcemia, which may be caused by vitamin D intoxication rather than deficiency.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1.
IL-1 is involved in pyroptosis, a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence:
• Activation of the inflammasome complex
• Activation of caspase-1
• Generation of IL-1 - results in fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment

questions.text: Which of the following helps the Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) to penetrate into the host cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


 The HIV virus can penetrate the host’s CD4+ cells with the help of the viral glycoprotein gp120, also known as the spike antigen which is present in its envelope. HIV-1 virion is spherical and contains an electron-dense, cone-shaped core surrounded by a lipid envelope derived from the host cell membrane. Target cells of HIV includeCD4+ helper T cells (worst affected), monocyte macrophages, and dendritic cells.

questions.text: Which of the following newly approved anti-diabetic drugs can be given for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and impaired renal function?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Empaglifozin, which is a sodium-glucose transporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor has been recently approved for use in patients with Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction, and can be initiated in patients with impaired renal function with estimated glomerular filtration rate > 20 mL/min/1.73 m2.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 65-year-old man is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The given image showing a solitary punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim with a beveled edge appearance, along with the history is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, sore throat, and dyspnea. On oral examination, a pseudomembrane is seen over the tonsils. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
This child with pseudomembrane over tonsil has diphtheria, in which the toxin inactivates the elongation factor EF-2. Diphtheria toxin is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments – A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa also produces toxins with a similar mechanism of action.

questions.text: What is the most common route of infection in acute suppurative otitis media?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Eustachian tube
The eustachian tube is the most common route of infection in acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). The infection travels via the lumen of the tube or along subepithelial peritubal lymphatics. It can also spread from the external ear through a traumatic perforation or via the blood but it is rare.

questions.text: The actions of the muscle marked in the image include:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intorsion, Depression, and Abduction
The muscle marked in the above image is the superior oblique. 
Actions of the superior oblique: 
•    Intorsion 
•    Depression 
•    Abduction

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rhinoscleroma
The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

questions.text: The pathognomonic feature of intermediate uveitis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Snow banking 
Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis.

questions.text: Interval of time between the receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of the host is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Generation time 
The time between the infection of a primary case and one of its secondary cases is called a generation time. The distribution (and mean) of the generation times is derived for a rather general class of epidemic models.

questions.text: The best option for correcting irregular astigmatism is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Contact lenses 
Placing a rigid gas permeable corneal lens or scleral lens on the eye and refracting over it will eliminate any irregular astigmatism from the front of the cornea.

questions.text: You are the ENT resident examining a patient in the wards. On asking him to swallow you notice the larynx moves upwards. Which of the following muscles is not responsible for this movement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sternohyoid
The sternohyoid is not responsible for upward movement (elevation). It is a depressor of the larynx. The extrinsic muscles of the larynx can be elevators or depressors.

questions.text: On examination of the retina, a student notes peculiar stripes on the retina like that seen in a tiger, so he notes down the finding as tigroid fundus. In which condition is it seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Myopia
Tigroid fundus myopia is a rare condition characterized by abnormal pigmentation and streaks in the back of the eye, particularly in individuals with severe myopia. These streaks resemble the stripes of a tiger, hence the name.

questions.text: Goals for MMR and IMR by 2030:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

70/30

Based on typical global health goals and targets, the most realistic and favorable goals for MMR (Maternal Mortality Ratio) and IMR (Infant Mortality Rate) by 2030 would generally be 70/30.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient complains of redness, tearing, and photophobia in both eyes. On examination, you observe bilateral corneal neovascularization and peripheral infiltrates. The patient is a contact lens wearer. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acanthamoeba keratitis
Bilateral corneal neovascularization, peripheral infiltrates, and a history of contact lens use are suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis, a parasitic infection that can occur in contact lens wearers.

questions.text: The body of a missing person was found tied up in a boat. During the autopsy, you notice the presence of the following organism in his brain tissue. Which of the following is not a possible cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Postmortem drowning 
The given image shows a diatom. Postmortem drowning does not show diatoms in the brain tissue. Diatoms are microscopic unicellular or colonial algae present in water. As the diatoms are found in both seawater and freshwater, their presence cannot differentiate between freshwater and seawater drowning.

questions.text: In which of the following fractures Le-Fort classification is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Maxilla
Le-Fort classification is used in the fracture of the maxilla.
The 3 types are:
•    Le Fort I (transverse fracture)
•    Le Fort II (pyramidal fracture)
•    Le Fort III (craniofacial disjunction)

questions.text: A 27-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gray

This patient with vaginal discharge and erosions on the cervix has cervicitis from a sexually transmitted infection. She should be given the gray kit which contains cefixime and azithromycin.

questions.text: Under HBNC, ASHA has to make how many numbers of home visits to a baby born in home delivery:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

7

ASHA has to make home visits to all newborns as per a schedule up to 42 days of life. Institutional delivery – 6 visits—Day 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42
Home delivery: 7 visits—Day 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.text: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

questions.text: A patient has unilateral ptosis and diplopia. On examination there was decreased movement of eyeball in all directions. Patient also complains of difficulty in reading news prints. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Occulomotor palsy
The third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerves innervate the extraocular muscles that position the globes in the orbits. Extraocular muscle paralysis resulting from lesions in one or all of these cranial nerves results in failure of one or both eyes to rotate in concert with the other eye. • The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axes, and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved.

questions.text: A 20 year old man complaints of reading difficulty in his right eye 5 weeks after a gunshot injury to his left eye. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sympathetic ophthalmitis 
Sympathetic ophthalmia is a rare, bilateral granulomatous uveitis that occurs after either surgical or accidental trauma to one eye. The ocular inflammation in the fellow eye becomes apparent usually within 3 months after injury.

questions.text: A patient with chronic dacryocystitis, refractory to the medical treatment, has been scheduled for dacryocystorhinostomy. Following the surgery, the sac would be draining into the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Middle meatus
After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.

questions.text: A male patient working in the matchbox industry for the past 20 years reports to the dentist with multiple sinuses and fistulae in and around his jaw with foul-smelling discharge. Which of the following chemicals are responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


The clinical scenario is suggestive of a phossy jaw, which occurs due to chronic phosphorus poisoning. Phossy jaw refers to osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses.
Frequent inhalation of phosphorus fumes causes necrosis of the lower jaw in the region of a decayed tooth. Patients initially present with toothache, followed by swelling of the jaw, loosening of the teeth, necrosis of gums, and sequestration of the bone in the mandible producing considerable facial disfigurement.
Chronic phosphorus poisoning is common among the workers of phosphorus industries (matchbox factories), who have had chronic exposure to phosphorus fumes for months to years. It is managed surgically and by prevention of further exposure to the poison.
Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms, white phosphorus, a highly toxic form, and red phosphorus, the nontoxic form.

questions.text: Which of these symptoms is least likely to be present in a patient diagnosed with Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Otalgia
Otalgia is least likely to be present in a patient diagnosed with Ménière’s disease.
The characteristic triad of Ménière’s disease includes:
1. Episodic vertigo-attacks come in clusters, with periods of spontaneous remission lasting for weeks, months, or years
2. Fluctuating hearing loss hearing is affected during episodes of vertigo, improves after the attack, and maybe normal during remissions
3. Tinnitus- low-pitched whistling or roaring type

questions.text: In a patient presenting with a conductive type of hearing loss, a negative Rinne test with a 512 Hz tuning fork indicates a minimum air-bone gap of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

30 dB
The negative Rinne test for 512 Hz indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 30 dB.

questions.text: A patient with known mutation in the 'Rb gene' is ‘disease free' from Retinoblastoma. The patient is at highest risk of developing which of the following malignancies OR The most common second malignancy in survivors of retinoblastoma is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Osteosarcoma 
Retinoblastoma is most common primary intraocular malignancy in childhood. Occurs due to mutation of RB1 gene located on 113q14. Pineloblastoma is most commonly associated with RB. Most common secondary malignant neoplasm is osteosarcoma.

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The given image shows an abrasion due to ligature mark, which is a pressure abrasion. Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to injury to the epidermis. They are usually caused by friction against a rough surface or by compression.

questions.text: USG done on a pregnant woman shows Spalding’s sign. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Maceration of fetus

USG showing Spalding’s sign is suggestive of maceration of the fetus. This sign refers to the overlapping of the fetal skull bones caused by the collapse of the fetal brain.

choices.text: Initiative for providing free sanitary pads
Initiative to provide vaccination to under-5 children
Initiative for labour room quality improvement
Initiative to provide affordable healthcare to all

questions.text: Which of the following does the Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refer to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Initiative for labour room quality improvement

The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refers to the initiative for labour room quality improvement.

questions.text: An ENT resident is evaluating a patient with suspected allergic rhinitis. On anterior rhinoscopy, which of the following is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pale and edematous mucosa
A patient with perennial allergic rhinitis will have a pale and edematous nasal mucosa with swollen turbinates. Crusts that bleed on removal and atrophied turbinates are features seen in atrophic rhinitis.

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Internal laryngeal nerve
The internal laryngeal nerve is the nerve implicated in the inhibition of the cough reflex in an alcoholic. Alcohol can cause chemical irritation of the nerve and it is also a potent inhibitor of the central nervous system. The cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel irritants and keep the airway clear. Chemical or mechanical irritation of the respiratory mucosa stimulates the afferent internal laryngeal nerve, which is the branch of the superior laryngeal nerve of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of buboes in the community. What is the vector responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Xenopsylla cheopis

The vector for bubonic plague is Xenopsylla cheopis. It is also called a rat flea. It also transmits murine typhus, chiggerosis, and hymenolepsis diminuta. It can be identified by the presence of a conical-shaped head, the presence of thorax, abdomen, and three pairs of legs.

questions.text: A patient with calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals in the urine is diagnosed with ethylene glycol poisoning. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fomepizole

Fomepizole is the drug of choice for the treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning.

questions.text: While performing tympanoplasty, the ENT surgeon notices that the floor of the middle ear is deficient. Which of the following structures is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Internal jugular vein
The internal jugular vein is susceptible to injury in this given clinical scenario. The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein. Occasionally, the floor is deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous membrane making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery.

questions.text: Which is the innermost layer of corneal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Columnar cells
The corneal epithelium consists of several layers of cells. The cells of the deepest layer are columnar, known as basal cells which are attached by multiprotein complexes known as hemidesmosomes to an underlying basement membrane.

questions.text: Gas shadow is present in the great vessels of a fetus in the case of intrauterine demise. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Gas shadow in the great vessels of a fetus in intrauterine death is called the Roberts sign. It is the earliest sign and is seen within 12 hours of death. The gas shadow may be present within the chambers of the heart or in large vessels of the fetus.
Signs of intrauterine death:
• Earliest sign - reddening of the skin with peeling in 12 hours
• Robert's sign - radiographic finding showing gas in the great vessels like the aorta in 12 hours
• Large blebs containing a red serous or serosanguineous fluid appear at around 24 hours
• Serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours
• Spalding's sign (Option B) radiographic finding is seen as a loss of alignment and overriding of bones of the cranial vault. This occurs due to shrinkage of the brain after death. It is seen 7 days after fetal death.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady complains of frequent change of presbyopic glasses and finds it difficult to adapt to darkness quickly. This is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Open angle glaucoma
It’s the most common type of Glucoma. First sign seen in open-angle glaucoma is Extension above blind spot. Patients usually complain of frequent changes in presbyopic glasses. Patients develop delayed dark adaptation. Fundus examination show large cup. (0.6 or more).

questions.text: Crippling fluorosis seen at level of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

>10 ppm
Crippling fluorosis, which is the severe form of fluorosis causing significant skeletal and dental changes, is typically seen at fluoride levels greater than 10 ppm (parts per million) in drinking water.

choices.text: She is trained for a period of 21 days
Works with the Village Health and Sanitation Committee
Act as depot holder for IFA, ORS
She is in the age group 25–45 years

questions.text: All of the following are true about ASHA except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

She is trained for a period of 21 days 

The induction training of ASHA is for 23 days in 5 episodes spread over 1 year.

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Letulle technique
The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique. It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks.

questions.text: A patient with acute coalescent mastoiditis undergoes cortical mastoidectomy. Which of the following is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Macewen’s triangle 
Macewen’s (suprameatal) triangle is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum. In an adult, the antrum lies 12-15 mm from the surface. This triangle is also the site of tenderness in acute mastoiditis.

choices.text: Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens

questions.text: Ligament of Weiger is the _____.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens 

Ligament of Weiger is attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens. The hyaloideo-capsular ligament of Weiger is the annular region (1-2 mm in width and 8-9 mm in diameter) where the vitreous is attached to the posterior aspect of the lens.

choices.text: Payable for maximum of period of 91 days
Extended benefit is payable for 309 days
Benefit is 30% of average daily wage
Viral fever is an indicator for extended benefit

questions.text: True regarding sickness benefit as per ESI Act 1948:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Payable for maximum of period of 91 days 
Option A: Correct 
Option B: Incorrect, it is till 2 years 
Option C: Incorrect, it is up to 70% of the wage

questions.text: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is caused by the deficiency of which layer of the tear film?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aqueous layer 


Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film.

questions.text: The treatment of paucibacillary leprosy consists of MDT (which comprises rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine). The latest recommended regimen is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

3 drug therapy for 6 months

The latest recommendation is 3 drug therapy for 6 months to treat paucibacillary (PB) leprosy by WHO. The regimen consists of rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine. Meanwhile, multibacillary (MB) leprosy is treated using the same 3 drugs for a duration of 12 months. While the NLEP guidelines earlier mentioned a 2-drug MDT for PB leprosy, the National Strategic Plan and Roadmap for Leprosy (2023- 2027) now recommends a uniform MDT of 3 drugs for both PB and MB leprosy.

questions.text: A person was found dead by his wife in his garage with his car running. Carbon monoxide gas poisoning was confirmed to be the cause of his death. What will be the color of post mortem staining in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cherry red 

The color of postmortem staining in carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is cherry red.

questions.text: A professional wrestler presents to your OPD with the deformity shown below. What is the most likely cause of the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Auricular hematoma 
The image shows a cauliflower ear deformity, which is likely due to auricular hematoma. Auricular hematoma is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium. If left untreated, the extravasated blood may clot and then organize, resulting in a typical deformity called cauliflower ear. It is also called pugilistic or boxer’s ear.

choices.text: Started from 2nd trimester till 6 months of lactation
From 1st trimester till 6 months of pregnancy

questions.text: True about Anaemia Mukt Bharat Program:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Started from 2nd trimester till 6 months of lactation
The Anaemia Mukt Bharat Program is a comprehensive strategy to combat anemia across life stages, including children, adolescents, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. One of the key components of the program is the provision of iron and folic acid (IFA) supplementation.

questions.text: A 48-year old construction worker presents to you with hearing loss. His audiogram reveals a diagnosis of noise-induced hearing loss. Which organ is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Organ of Corti 
The organ of Corti is the sensory organ of hearing and is situated on the basilar membrane. Chronic exposure to loud noises may mechanically damage the organ of Corti and result in noise induced hearing loss.

questions.text: Moll glands are examples of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Apocrine sweat glands 
Moll glands are a type of modified apocrine sweat glands opening either into a lash follicle or directly onto the anterior lid margin between the lashes. 
Zeis glands are a type of modified sebaceous glands associated with lash follicles. 
Meibomian glands are modified sebaceous glands found in the tarsal plates.

questions.text: Laser used to manage after cataract:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nd:YAG laser 
The Nd:YAG laser is a solid state laser that uses a neodymium-doped yttrium-aluminum-garnet crystal as the lasing medium. It is optically pumped with a lamp or diode and most commonly emits infrared light at 1064nm. It can be used in either a pulsed or continuous mode. Pulsed YAG lasers are typically Qswitched to achieve high-intensity pulses, which can be frequency doubled to emit light at 532nm.

choices.text: 60 mg elemental iron daily ; 20mg kids syrup
40 mg elemental iron daily; 20mg kids syrup
200 mg elemental iron daily; 40mg kids syrup
400 mg elemental iron daily; 20mg kids syrup

questions.text: In India, what is the recommended dose of iron tablets for pregnant women as part of antenatal care and also for kids iron syrup ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

60 mg elemental iron daily; 20mg kids syrup 

The recommended dose of iron tablets for pregnant women in India is typically 60 mg of elemental iron daily. 20mg in kids syrup.

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of cold water drowning.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
In cold water drowning or immersion syndrome or hydrocution, death occurs due to vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest. Hydrocution/ immersion syndrome refers to sudden death, following immersion in cold water. Death results from vagal inhibition of the heart, i.e. cardiac arrest occurring due to increased stimulation of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: The prevention of emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Primordial prevention

Primordial prevention is a concept that precedes primary prevention and focuses on risk factor prevention.
